title: Planning Ahead With MS

content: I learned in Boy Scouts to be prepared, to plan ahead for what might come. But how do you plan if you have a disease as totally unpredictable as multiple sclerosis (MS)? When you don’t know from one day, month, or year to the next how your body and mind will function?

Most people don’t even try. We just say take care of yourself, try to find a good doctor, and hope for the best. Sometimes that works, but more often, we face unnecessary suffering and limitations because we didn’t prepare.
Nobody wants to spend time and money preparing for complications that may never happen, but here are some things you might want to consider.
Home Accessibility

Are there stairs inside or outside your house you have to climb? Maybe you can climb them now, but what if your MS progresses? I was very lucky in this, or maybe I was smart. I lived in a two-bedroom apartment, in which the bedrooms and bathroom were upstairs.

Home Accessibility

Are there stairs inside or outside your house you have to climb? Maybe you can climb them now, but what if your MS progresses? I was very lucky in this, or maybe I was smart. I lived in a two-bedroom apartment, in which the bedrooms and bathroom were upstairs.

content: At the time, I could make it up and down, but it was getting so the stairs tired me out, and I was afraid of falling. I was walking with a cane at the time, and I worried. What would happen if I couldn’t handle the stairs? I’d have been stuck in my bedroom forever.

So, I got a letter from my doctor saying I couldn’t safely handle stairs. My apartment was part of a huge rental complex, and the managers agreed to let me move into a high-rise with elevators, no stairs. We took the offer, and I am so grateful. Just a few weeks after moving, my legs got much weaker. I would have been immobilized in the old place.
You might not be facing concerns like that, and I hope you never do. But you might want to consider getting chair lifts for stairs, or building a ramp to get up and down, if walking becomes too hard.

It helps to have accessible bathrooms, too. It will cost some money to renovate a bathroom to make room for a wheelchair or scooter, but grip bars for getting in and out of showers and toilets are cheap and easy. Walk-in showers are also popular now, and some are big enough to roll into.

content: Obviously, owning your own home is very different from renting. If you want to remodel, you just need the money to do it. With renting, you might need your landlord’s permission. You might need to move to a more accessible place. You might need assistance to find one. If you’re old enough, there might be senior housing available, and disabled people can often qualify at a younger age.

Moving from a house of your own to a rental apartment is a big change, and lots of people will not consider it, but I like not being responsible for repairs or maintenance, and I like having people around with whom I can make friends. If I was living in a house in the suburbs now, I’d be sad and lonely.
My point is, don’t wait until you need modifications to start planning. It’s very hard to find a place, move into it, and get it set up as a disabled person. I’m so glad I moved while I still could.

sections.heading: Getting Around
content: If we can’t go anywhere, we won’t enjoy life much, and our activities will be very limited. Let’s say you can walk a block or two, but it wears you out and you sometimes fall. The first thing is mobility aids for walking. In order of disability, these include canes, quad canes, walkers, walkers with a seat (now often called rollators), mobility scooters, and power chairs.
Nobody wants to use those assists. They’re not sexy, but if the alternative is staying at home, we should be brave and try them. Sometimes a physical therapist (PT) can help us decide what’s best.

So, you can walk. Now what? If you like driving and have a car, you can consider hand controls to help you operate it. The website BraunAbility says they can cost from $2,700 to $8,000. If you’re in a wheelchair, there are minivans that you can roll into right up to the steering wheel. Looking at things like that online or in a disability supply store might make you feel more hopeful about the future.

content: Personally, I never liked driving and was happy to give it up. In San Francisco, all the buses are scooter accessible, and these days I rarely even get into a car. If I lived out in the country or a distant suburb, it would be different.

I have to admit to choosing where I go and what I do based on how close to public transit they are. Another alternative is paratransit. Most counties have transportation for disabled people, and it’s usually pretty affordable. I have a friend with MS who met her boyfriend when he picked her up for paratransit.
Avoiding Poverty

The scariest risk for most people with MS is, “How will I make money? What if I can’t work?” I’m not going into that much here; I’ve written about it before, [link] but we should prepare for a potential disability claim. Applying for disability requires a lot of paperwork, and we need to keep all our doctor’s records neatly organized just in case. We should also be thinking of what work we can do in our current job or some other one. We can also think of a business we could run with less physical ability, or a job we can do from home on a computer.

sections.heading: Friends
content: Loneliness is a major complication of MS, as I wrote about here . Disability makes it hard to make new friends. You have to get out to meet them, and you have to have the confidence to introduce yourself.

In my experience, it’s easier to keep the friends I already have. MS can make that harder, too, because we might not feel up to doing the things we used to do with friends. I try to come up with new things that are still fun. These usually turn out to be old-people things like art galleries or museums, book clubs, or restaurants. But sometimes a new thing is fun. Last month, I went to an escape room at Fisherman’s Wharf with my son and granddaughter, and it was great.

sections.heading: Maximize Function
content: Of course, the best thing is not to need these modifications. We should keep moving as much as possible. My PT and OT friends recommend that you don’t just work the disabled parts of your body. Exercise the more functional parts, too, because our bodies put energy into the things we care about. That’s why they say, “Use it or lose it.”

content: You might also want to prepare for the best. Things you’d like to do if MS doesn’t get in the way, things you might build up to. Those are good. But don’t forget home accessibility and mobility issues, or you might regret it.
